trans-unit.target: Reliable Actors design pattern: smart cache

trans-unit.source: The combination of a web tier, caching tier, storage tier, and occasionally a worker tier are pretty much the standard parts of today’s applications.
trans-unit.target: The combination of a web tier, caching tier, storage tier, and occasionally a worker tier are pretty much the standard parts of today’s applications.

trans-unit.source: The caching tier is usually vital to performance and may, in fact, be comprised of multiple tiers itself.
trans-unit.target: The caching tier is usually vital to performance and may, in fact, be comprised of multiple tiers itself.

trans-unit.source: Many caches are simple key-value pairs while other systems like [Redis](http://redis.io) that are used as caches offer richer semantics.
trans-unit.target: Many caches are simple key-value pairs while other systems like [Redis](http://redis.io) that are used as caches offer richer semantics.

trans-unit.source: Still, any special, caching tier will be limited in semantics and more importantly it is yet another tier to manage.
trans-unit.target: Still, any special, caching tier will be limited in semantics and more importantly it is yet another tier to manage.

trans-unit.source: What if instead, objects just kept state in local variables and these objects can be snapshotted or persisted to a durable store automatically?
trans-unit.target: What if instead, objects just kept state in local variables and these objects can be snapshotted or persisted to a durable store automatically?

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, rich collections such as lists, sorted sets, queues, and any other custom type for that matter are simply modelled as member variables and methods.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, rich collections such as lists, sorted sets, queues, and any other custom type for that matter are simply modelled as member variables and methods.

trans-unit.source: The leaderboard sample
trans-unit.target: The leaderboard sample

trans-unit.source: Take leader boards as an example—a Leaderboard object needs to maintain a sorted list of players and their scores so that we can query it.
trans-unit.target: Take leader boards as an example—a Leaderboard object needs to maintain a sorted list of players and their scores so that we can query it.

trans-unit.source: For example for the "Top 100 Players" or to find a player’s position in the leader board relative to +- N players above and below him/her.
trans-unit.target: For example for the "Top 100 Players" or to find a player’s position in the leader board relative to +- N players above and below him/her.

trans-unit.source: A typical solution with traditional tools would require ‘GET’ing the Leaderboard object (collection which supports inserting a new tuple<Player, Points> named Score), sorting it, and finally ‘PUT’ing it back to the cache.
trans-unit.target: A typical solution with traditional tools would require ‘GET’ing the Leaderboard object (collection which supports inserting a new tuple<Player, Points> named Score), sorting it, and finally ‘PUT’ing it back to the cache.

trans-unit.source: We would probably LOCK (GETLOCK, PUTLOCK) the Leaderboard object for consistency.
trans-unit.target: We would probably LOCK (GETLOCK, PUTLOCK) the Leaderboard object for consistency.

trans-unit.source: Let’s have an actor-based solution where state and behaviour are together.
trans-unit.target: Let’s have an actor-based solution where state and behaviour are together.

trans-unit.source: There are two options:
trans-unit.target: There are two options:

trans-unit.source: Implement the Leaderboard Collection as part of the actor,
trans-unit.target: Implement the Leaderboard Collection as part of the actor,

trans-unit.source: Or use the actor as an interface to the collection that we can keep in a member variable.
trans-unit.target: Or use the actor as an interface to the collection that we can keep in a member variable.

trans-unit.source: It may feel like the example above could create a bottleneck in the Leaderboard instance.
trans-unit.target: It may feel like the example above could create a bottleneck in the Leaderboard instance.

trans-unit.source: What if, for instance, we are planning to support hundreds and thousands of players?
trans-unit.target: What if, for instance, we are planning to support hundreds and thousands of players?

trans-unit.source: One way to deal with that might be to introduce stateless aggregators that would act like a buffer—hold the partial scores (say subtotals) and then periodically send them to the Leaderboard actor, which can maintain the final Leaderboard.
trans-unit.target: One way to deal with that might be to introduce stateless aggregators that would act like a buffer—hold the partial scores (say subtotals) and then periodically send them to the Leaderboard actor, which can maintain the final Leaderboard.

trans-unit.source: We will discuss this “aggregation” technique in more detail later.
trans-unit.target: We will discuss this “aggregation” technique in more detail later.

trans-unit.source: Also, we do not have to consider mutexes, semaphores, or other concurrency constructs traditionally required by correctly behaving concurrent programs.
trans-unit.target: Also, we do not have to consider mutexes, semaphores, or other concurrency constructs traditionally required by correctly behaving concurrent programs.

trans-unit.source: Actors provide flexibility
trans-unit.target: Actors provide flexibility

trans-unit.source: In the samples above, Leaderboard and JobQueue, we used two different techniques:
trans-unit.target: In the samples above, Leaderboard and JobQueue, we used two different techniques:

trans-unit.source: In the Leaderboard sample we encapsulated a Leaderboard object as a private member variable in the actor and merely provided an interface to this object – both to its state and functionality.
trans-unit.target: In the Leaderboard sample we encapsulated a Leaderboard object as a private member variable in the actor and merely provided an interface to this object – both to its state and functionality.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, in the JobQueue sample we implemented the actor as a priority queue itself rather than referencing another object defined elsewhere.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, in the JobQueue sample we implemented the actor as a priority queue itself rather than referencing another object defined elsewhere.

trans-unit.source: Actors provide flexibility for the developer to define rich object structures as part the actors or reference object graphs outside of the actors.
trans-unit.target: Actors provide flexibility for the developer to define rich object structures as part the actors or reference object graphs outside of the actors.

trans-unit.source: In caching terms actors can write-behind or write-through, or we can use different techniques at a member variable granularity.
trans-unit.target: In caching terms actors can write-behind or write-through, or we can use different techniques at a member variable granularity.

trans-unit.source: In other words, we have full control over what to persist and when to persist.
trans-unit.target: In other words, we have full control over what to persist and when to persist.

trans-unit.source: We don’t have to persist transient state or state that we can build from saved state.
trans-unit.target: We don’t have to persist transient state or state that we can build from saved state.

trans-unit.source: And how about populating these actors caches then?
trans-unit.target: And how about populating these actors caches then?

trans-unit.source: There are number of ways to achieve this.
trans-unit.target: There are number of ways to achieve this.

trans-unit.source: Actors provide virtual methods called OnActivateAsync() and OnDectivateAsync() to let us know when an instance of the actor is activated and deactivated.
trans-unit.target: Actors provide virtual methods called OnActivateAsync() and OnDectivateAsync() to let us know when an instance of the actor is activated and deactivated.

trans-unit.source: Note that the actor is activated on demand when a first request is sent to it.
trans-unit.target: Note that the actor is activated on demand when a first request is sent to it.

trans-unit.source: We can use OnActivateAsync() to populate state on-demand as in read-through, perhaps from an external stable store.
trans-unit.target: We can use OnActivateAsync() to populate state on-demand as in read-through, perhaps from an external stable store.

trans-unit.source: Or we can populate state on a timer, say an Exchange Rate actor that provides the conversion function based on the latest currency rates.
trans-unit.target: Or we can populate state on a timer, say an Exchange Rate actor that provides the conversion function based on the latest currency rates.

trans-unit.source: This actor can populate its state from an external service periodically, say every 5 seconds, and use the state for the conversion function.
trans-unit.target: This actor can populate its state from an external service periodically, say every 5 seconds, and use the state for the conversion function.

trans-unit.source: Essentially Smart Cache provides:
trans-unit.target: Essentially Smart Cache provides:

trans-unit.source: High throughput/low latency by service requests from memory.
trans-unit.target: High throughput/low latency by service requests from memory.

trans-unit.source: Single-instance routing and single-threaded serialization of requests to an item with no contention on persistent store.
trans-unit.target: Single-instance routing and single-threaded serialization of requests to an item with no contention on persistent store.

trans-unit.source: Semantic operations, for example, Enqueue(Job item).
trans-unit.target: Semantic operations, for example, Enqueue(Job item).

trans-unit.source: Easy-to-implement write-through or write-behind.
trans-unit.target: Easy-to-implement write-through or write-behind.

trans-unit.source: Automatic eviction of LRU (Least Recently Used) items (resource management).
trans-unit.target: Automatic eviction of LRU (Least Recently Used) items (resource management).

trans-unit.source: Automatic elasticity and reliability.
trans-unit.target: Automatic elasticity and reliability.
